title: 113_s2005
content: The Act may be cited as the "CLEAR Cost Information Act of 2013". It involves the reporting of certain hospital payment data. The Social Security Act is being amended in various subsections, including adding new subparagraphs and redesignating existing ones. The Social Security Act is being amended to include new reporting requirements for subsection (d) hospitals, with changes to subparagraphs and the addition of a new subsection for reporting hospital payment data to the Secretary. The Social Security Act is being amended to include new reporting requirements for subsection (d) hospitals. Hospitals must report payment data to the Secretary for uninsured and insured patients for the 50 most common procedures over the previous 2 years. The procedures described in paragraph (2) involve reporting the 50 most common diagnosis-related groups and ambulatory payment classification groups for payment under the Social Security Act. Transparency is required in reporting this data for public benefit. The Secretary must ensure transparent public availability of hospital data, allowing for comparisons by zip code and consumer understanding. Hospitals must link this data on their websites. Effective date for these amendments is specified. The amendments require hospitals to link data on their websites for consumer transparency and comparison by zip code. Effective date is specified for these changes. The amendments mandate that MedPAC's annual reports to Congress include data on the percentage of charity care provided by hospitals. Additionally, a report on charity care trends from certain hospitals must be made publicly available. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act is amended to require the Secretary of the Treasury to post data on a publicly accessible website for meaningful comparisons by zip code. Additionally, hospitals must provide a link to this data on their home webpage as per Medicare requirements. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act now mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to publish data on a public website for zip code comparisons. Hospitals are also required by Medicare to include a link to this data on their homepage. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act mandates hospitals to include a link on their website to data posted for zip code comparisons. This requirement applies to contracts entered into or renewed after the enactment of the Act.
